segments.text: This is Ryan Jorgensen.
The date is November 18th, 1985.
We're in the Trigon at Texas A&M University in College Station.
And today I'm interviewing Colonel Donald Burton about his experiences in Vietnam.
Colonel Burton, can you tell me your birthplace and date?
Yes, I was born in Waco, Texas, April 14th, 1935.
Okay, thank you.
And when were you stationed in Vietnam?
I went to Vietnam on two occasions.
The first time was in 1966 in Vietnam.
in the spring.
That was a temporary duty assignment.
I went there with a team of people from a field artillery school, primarily to work on the maintenance situation with 8 inch and 175 millimeter howitzers, which had a tremendous deadline rate.
That means that they were inoperative.
And our mission was to go over and find out why the weapon system was not doing well in Vietnam, and number two, to conduct classes on maintenance.
parts supply and operation of the thing.
That started out to be a two-week trip, which wound up being about a two-month stay.
I see.
And what was your second visit?
Second was my assignment there.
I went over with 41st Artillery Group in 1967.
I see.
What did you find with your weapons?
Well, we found typically that the weapons were being poorly maintained.
Parts supply system was not working properly at any level and there was quite a bit of abuse of the weapons system and it's just a typical thing, you know, you publish
instructions and lessons learned on how to operate the system, but whether people read it or not is something else again.
So it's very profitable because we cured that problem within a six-week period of time.
Oh, that's good.
I see.
And how long was your second assignment?
A year.
One year.
Yeah, I stayed a year.
Okay.
And what did that entail with the 41st?
My assignment with the 41st Artillery Group, I was the group adjutant, which the group adjutant runs the administration,
the personnel and the discipline systems for an organization.
I spent six months with the 41st Artillery Group all over Vietnam because that group had nine battalions under it.
And then became the S-1 or the personnel staff officer for 1st Field Force Artillery Headquarters, which is the core artillery headquarters station in Nha Trang.
I see.
What was our overall strategy in Vietnam?
Well, that varies in what year you're talking about.
When you were there, in 67?
Well, basically in early days, our strategy was one of combat.
We were attempting to engage both the PLA forces, or VC forces, if you will, and main force forces where we found them.
So there was a considerable amount of what's called
search and destroy missions and circumvent missions, forays, raids, the whole works.

Also, there was a considerable effort in the mid-60s to do a lot of stabilization at the local level in support of the school systems, to assist in land reform, to assist in keeping the communication routes open, and so forth.
And how successful were those?
Well, it was very successful.
I think that...
On a localized basis now.
You have to realize that on a national basis, we didn't have the same thing.
If we had, you wouldn't have the continual collapse of governments that you saw.
And it's very important to realize that what went on at the local level and what went on at the national level was two different things.
And the tie-in between the two wasn't often good because we did not take over that country.
We just tried to encourage their own government to establish itself and run it.
And the biggest problem was what I call a political communication between the government of Saigon and on down to the states, the districts, the villages, and right on down.
It's just a tremendously different thing.
The government of Saigon was corrupt and inefficient?
Well, I can't comment on being corrupt and inefficient.
I think that when you say corrupt and inefficient, you're talking about Oriental governments in general, by our standards.
But certainly...
We saw during that era of a few short years a change of government about four times.
So I don't think anybody was too happy with the governments at hand, and they collapsed one after the other.
How well did the military attack adapt to the jungle environment of Vietnam?
Well, I think that we had
Good training going on.
I think we had a good program to introduce people into the country.
We just didn't bring soldiers in and stick them out in the jungle.
Most people had training programs on the ground once they got there.
You made sure a guy really did know how to handle his weapons.
It was acclimatized.
And prior to deployment in those days, remember,
that was an era of deployment because we were building up.
So most people going over were going as units and not as individual replacements, which came later in the early 70s.
So in those days, the units that were going over were getting considerable training before they were shipped to Vietnam.
And as good a surrogate environment as could be built on several military installations with constructed villages and things like that.
Were we prepared for guerrilla warfare?
Oh, I don't think that the lack of preparation for guerrilla warfare was ever an issue.
The answer to that is yes.
We held our own.
We went to school on the British successes in Malaysia.
We had taken good look at everything going on in Indonesia.
We were students of what the French had done right and wrong.
So as far as at the small unit level,
Climbing ties into the various crane situations was not a problem, nor what you call guerrilla warfare, which is really small unit warfare.
So the snipers and the booby traps and so on did not... We were just as good as they were at that.
It's all very mean stuff, but you learn to cope with that.
In fact, I don't think that...
any organization was quite effective as our Green Beret organizations in that area were quite good.
How were the Green Berets special?
Well, that was their forte.
That was their training.
Their training was to operate in small units under adverse conditions and independently.
But it was an organization that was designed not only to fight, but to have political influence, to have influence on organization of villages, to
to do a wide gamut of things not just related to combat.
They're a development agency, if you will, which had a combat role.
And how much of a percentage were the Green Braids in relation to the total forces?
I really would hesitate to speculate on that.
I'm sure there are statistics available.
But in terms of
The number of divisions and independent regiments there, the Green Berets were probably 120 up to that point.
And how would the other 1920s be rated?
Well, all of our divisions were good.
The 1st Cavalry Division, 1st Marine Division, 4th Infantry Division, 101st Airborne Division, all those were, the 9th Division, all those did quite well.
Of course, what they were doing is they were having to invent
the tactics that worked along the way because we did exceedingly well in combat against main force units and against Viet Cong which were organized into battalions.
But you have to realize that this was a very protracted war and frequently you weren't in combat simply because you couldn't find those you wanted to combat.
I imagine.
How closely did we work with Arvin?
Very closely.
We have probably one of the most elaborate military advisory and military mission systems ever fielded with respect to working with the Vietnamese Army.
Every unit in the Vietnamese Army and Air Force
to company level and often to platoon level, had US advisors who were there to help them train and to work.
Very frequently, their approach to their tactics and their operations was totally different than ours.
What would be some of the differences?
Well, you have to understand that while we wanted to get in there and win the battle, they might not
wish to do that unless they were politically expedient to do so.
So you have a lot of vested self-interest in that military structure they had and a lot of, well, political ploy, if you will, because that's just New Orleans.
And particularly the Vietnamese are completely totally different.
How do you encircle ploy?
Well, first off,
Frequently a commander of some unit would want to know what the rewards to him would be to conduct an attack as opposed to being devoted to the mission.
But the Western, and particularly U.S. approach to combat is somewhat different than the Oriental approach.
I imagine.
It's a strange way to fight a war.
Well, it's not strange to be at the meeting zone.
Were they quality fighters?
Some of the Vietnamese army forces were outstanding soldiers.
22nd Army Division in particular, which I probably had more contact with than anybody, were very good.
But you also had a lot of regional and territorial forces, which were less trained.
And you also have to understand that in Vietnam, you've got a Vietnamese culture that traces itself back to 500 B.C.
But you also have about 15% of the population which are minorities, tribesmen, not really the Vietnamese central culture that you think of.
They were less well-trained and less well-organized, less well-equipped, and considerably less motivated.
I see.
And yet they were considered part of Arvin all the same.
Well, you know, while we, as well as the Arvin, would think of Arvin
taking charge of and controlling areas of terrain, real estate, if you will, they were less inclined to be worried about that.
If things weren't favorable, they just moved off somewhere.

That brings up something that I've read a lot, that in a lot of cases, we weren't so much concerned with terrain as just with the body counts and with, you know, killing VC rather than... Well, I don't know that that was the case at the unit level.
Quite honestly,

in especially in later years body count got to be a sort of a measure of success which i really question because that's that's not a very good measure i don't think most soldiers accept that as a good measure simply because it's a long-term result that counts not how many people you killed on a particular day and
The body count thing really got to be a measure of success, if you will, when someone was trying to estimate the effectiveness of opposing forces after a battle.
In other words, were they a viable, effective force anymore?
And of course, that's not really key in making a difference how many people are killed in battle.
What really counts is the ultimate outcome.
and the stability that does or does not result thereafter.
I see.
So why did we use body count?
Well, my personal perspective, that's what the civilians were demanding.
Results in one form or another?
Sure, results.
And it's just very unfortunate that we ran some things the way we did.
I have personally felt that...

the business of six month command tours for commanders was a disaster because you keep changing commanders every six months and you just don't have the opportunity to really settle into your area of responsibility with a group of professionals.
And too often, I'm afraid, commanders try to make their mark in that six months rather than waging a prolonged and protracted approach to what their responsibilities were.
was also very much not in favor of the one-year tour.
What would be a good line?
I think that we should have put soldiers in there and left until we won.

We've done that in other wars, and why this one was run that way, I don't know, except for obvious pressures and lack of support within civilian populations in the United States for the war in the first place.
So I think that was more of an expedient to make that a one-year tour, get in and get out.
And, of course, the result of that is when you've got a new soldier in,
It was probably in his eighth month that he really became effective and really acclimatized.
And you could depend on him to be a really good warrior.
And then with the 12-month tour, by the time he hit his 10th month, he didn't want to take chances anymore.
So I guess your peak of efficiency was there 8th through the 10th month, and you kind of had to work with that attitude.
Why was the officer only six months, the officer's tour only six months long?
Why was it shorter?
Well, for a variety of reasons.
With a one-year tour, I think what they like to do is put people in command and then bring them up with their experience to work at the staff levels.
Also, it gave more people an opportunity to serve in command positions.
Now, one of the things that is kind of a curiosity but very true, one thing that a one-year tour and a six-month command did, it put a lot of Americans through Vietnam.
That is one thing we have as an advantage over the Russians, because our military today, especially those who serve in Vietnam, have combat experience.
A lot of them got it in various jobs.
And the Russians don't have that.
They're getting it right now in Afghanistan.
But unfortunately, most of those officers are not the Russians we'll be looking at in Europe.
Was the mass amount of bombing necessary and effective?
Some of the so-called saturation bombing is very effective.
Some of it wasn't.
And I think that, you know, I'm a field artilleryman, so I can speak to the delivery of indirect fires, too.
When I first arrived in 67, there was quite a bit of shelling going on based on sightings of VC activity that maybe even trained myself.
We got that.

stopped early on because it's number one not cost effective and number two useless so our intelligence began to improve because we began to get commanders in the field artillery who realized it was futile to shoot shells out there unless you had a real target the so-called harassment and interdiction fires is uh ineffective you know that's that's just sort of a
deal where you shoot it out there, and if somebody's there to find or not, you just wasted it.
Well, out of that, it lulls the operation into thinking that they're being affected when they're not.
And what you really have to do is put the heat on the intelligence community.
And in Vietnam, that was one of our major problems, was the collection of intelligence.
Why?
Well, because you're dealing with a totally alien environment and a society whose attitudes
and values are completely different from you, and who realize the protracted nature of any type of war.
So you really had to work to get your intelligence and then make sure it was accurate.
Did we have much of an intelligence complex set up before?
Oh yeah, we had tremendous intelligence effort both in surveillance
human intelligence, and crypto intelligence, the whole thing, and very effective, too.
But sometimes the timing of when you got your intelligence was such that it was no longer of value to you immediately on a battlefield because it was so old by the time you got it.
Oh, and it wasn't his impression.
Most of the real successes came because battles developed, starting from what might wind up as a skirmish between two patrols
which developed into a confrontation between two divisions before it was over with.
So by accident rather than planned invasion?
Not necessarily by accident, but they had a very good system of protecting their locations also.
How would you rate the American military leadership in Vietnam?
Well, it varied.
Pretty obviously, that's well documented.
We had some outstanding leadership and we had some that probably wasn't so good.
I think one of the unique
studies and leadership and the failure thereof as contained in the Peers Committee report, which I mentioned you might want to read, which led up to the knee line thing.

And really that was a very tragic incident that need not have ever occurred if people understood what their mission was and if the entire chain of command had been down there making sure the orders had been properly interpreted and carried out.
So why do you think they did occur?
Largely, you have a situation where you had a unit which had taken a lot of casualties.
You had leadership which, at the company level, which probably wasn't the best.
And you had an interpretation of orders and instructions which was singularly devised by people
at company level.
And I think you had at battalion and above level a kind of an urging of the units involved that you better do a good job this time.
You haven't in the past.
Their heads are going to roll if this operation doesn't go smoothly.
And then I think that there was some confusion in the orders that were issued from division level on down.
How did they get Garvin?
Well, I think they were not clear.
and that they were interpreted at every level, and that people who issued the orders in the first place were not in a position to make sure the plan was going the way they had directed.

And one of the criticisms I've had, and it's a real quandary problem, is that we had too many commanders who spent their time flying around in helicopters over the battlefield, and they could not get down on the battlefield and influence the action when they needed to.
Why is that?
Why were they in the helicopter?
Communication, primarily.
You can see more, you can communicate further, but you lack that sense of being there when you're on the end of a radio and flying over the battlefield.
So it just leaves interpretations of what the mission was to the people who are on the ground and you're not there to stop things or change things when they need to be.
Was there much inter-service rivalry in Vietnam between the various?
No, I wouldn't say there was inter-service rivalry, at least at my operating level.
There may have been up above.
I'm sure everybody wants to grab the glory, you know.
But as far as an actual combat situation, there's a great deal of cooperation.
What does the word fragging mean?
Oh, well, that referred to a phenomenon that began to take place in the late 70s.
I'd left, so I never heard of a frag against that point.
I'd left in 1968.
In the early 70s, I think continuing weakness in leadership and continuing lack of support for the mission, kind of a...
improper indoctrination of the soldiers that were sitting there.
Above all, dragging the bottom of the barrel at some of the draftees and inductees we were getting at the time and the drug problems that were being imported caused the so-called fragging.
Fragging just means that somebody has thrown a grenade in their platoon leader or platoon sergeant's temp, which is a form of mutiny, if you will.
Those incidents were highly overplayed.
That occurred, but not to the great degree that I think the public was awful at believing.
And when it did occur, you probably found a breakdown of leadership or a group of people that should have been gotten out of there early.
Was there much drug use?
Yeah, toward the end, quite a bit.
Sure.
Why?
Why?
Look at the population of the United States.
The whole population was on drugs.
Why not the soldiers that were being sent over there?
They probably had more anxiety and cause to experiment with marijuana and other things and people back up.
And how much effect do you think that had on our ability to fight effectively?
Well, I think it screwed up the whole nation's morale.
I don't think that got turned around until within the last five years, as a matter of fact.
In Vietnam, did it affect the soldier?
How much did it affect the armed forces, their ability to fight?
I think it had a tremendous impact because obviously somebody's got his head screwed up, can't be relied on, nor trusted in any form, shape, or fashion.
How did you perceive that the media handled the coverage of the war?
Oh, that was very independent.
Independent on who you're talking to.
The biggest problem I had with, quote, media was not the media themselves.
And there were a lot of outstanding correspondents that I knew that did a tremendous job.
But they began to be so pressed for deadlines that if the
the news by a certain time, and frequently they would turn in anything that looked like a story even before it transpired.
You know, when you start a battle, particularly around 5 o'clock in the afternoon, it doesn't even really get good until about 8 p.m.
But those guys are all left at 5.15 to make their deadlines, so they never were around for the real stuff too often.
But the guy that went to the field and stayed with you did a good job.
And we're talking correspondence there as opposed to...
television and radio folks who I thought did somewhat less of a professional job.
How so?
Well, they just were news makers rather than reporters.
If there wasn't anything going on, they'd admit something.
And did that affect the Dwar effort at home adversely?
I don't think there's any question, but what slanted reporting, particularly in the television media,
undoubtedly had an impact on the national morale.
On the other hand, I would not lay a blanket criticism on the press either, or the television, because I think that many of the things they reported on that sounded adverse were probably accurate.
How did you view draft evaders and anti-war activists?
Well, you know, nobody likes a draft evader and a guy who runs off to Canada or Sweden.
But you have to realize that's occurred in every war we've been in.
There were far fewer draft evaders and deserters and so forth in the Vietnam War than there were in the U.S. Civil War.
By a wide margin.
But look at the statistics.
Nobody ever thinks of that.
In fact, there were very few, compared to places, even compared to the Korean War.
If you go dig out the facts.
Even in the late 70s with the state movement and everything else getting... Yeah, I'd say so.
So did it have much of an effect on troop morale?
I don't think it had much of an effect on troop morale.
I mean, the troops didn't like them.
But then, many troops didn't like guys who hid out in colleges getting degree after degree and their PhDs simply to avoid military service.
And some of them are now faculty.
I imagine.
So what was the mood in Vietnam when you left in 68, is that right?
Yeah.
What was the mood then?
Well, first off, when you say when I left, that's a good one, because I left in April, and recall that we'd had a major 10 offensive in 68 in February.
Now, clearly at our level, at the soldier level, we knew damn well we would have kicked the dickens out of them, there was no question.
It was an absolute decimation of a couple of main divisions and the V.C.
Front Army.
Now, having said that, it was also obvious at higher levels that they had demonstrated their ability to launch such an attack.
And I think that most people had accepted assurances, accurately or inaccurately, which probably were delivered for political purposes that no such thing could occur.
So I think it was a general shake-up of the, shall we say, the confidence at governmental levels.
I think this led to some, while we won the battle on the ground, we probably lost the battle on the political level, particularly at the negotiating tables.
What was your role specifically in Tet?
What was your, or were you?
Well, as I say, I was personnel officer of the 1st Steel Artillery in the train.
We got hit directly there.
Basically, my role was to sit out the night and keep things secure in my area until we got things looked up in the morning.
It was largely a matter of ensuring that the security plans for the city were operating, and they were.
When you say personnel officer, what
What did that entail?

Oh, the personnel officer is responsible for all assignments, replacements, casualties, decorations and awards, moving people from one place to another, keeping the strength up, making sure that the medical facility's working, making sure the chaplain's working, you name it.
It's everything to do with the life of the soldier, if you will.
I see.
Why did we lose the war?
I don't think we lost the war.
I think that's a matter of conjecture there.
I think that I think the real thing here is not a matter of losing, it's a matter of deciding if we had invested enough into it and withdrawing.
I wouldn't call it lost because that pretends that you got beat on the battlefield right out of country and that certainly isn't what occurred.
We started withdrawing
and cutting our support because I think our national leaders decided that that was a sump of national manpower and national
fortunate that we didn't want to support any more, which is unfortunate.
What would it have taken to have won?
I don't know.
But if we had a commitment to do so, we should have stuck with it.
And is it in politics?
Well, certainly.
That's the basis for having a war anyway, is the political aspect.
There are six elements of national power, and the political one is the one that's supposed to be preeminent in a situation like this.
element fails and the statesmanship fails, then you go to war.
What are you going to do?
You've got to give a mission and make sure it's clearly understood.
That's one of the biggest troubles the military had, was understanding what their mission was.
You know, you're going to conduct an attack in order to stabilize the government of South Vietnam.
Hell, that's not a mission.
If your mission is to destroy, seize, hold, occupy, that's a mission.
But these nebulous things with respect to designing military missions in political terms just don't happen.
What else could we have done outside of the military arena in order to make it a national mission?
Well, in the first place, I think one of the major lessons learned is that you do not
get into an involvement like that on that scale unless you're willing to commit the nation to do it.
We just learned the same lesson the French did.
The French people got tired of being involved and that's why the French wound up in a situation of being given food.
So would it have taken more civilian advisors?
Should we have started at the village level?
We already had people in the division at the village level.
You have to realize that Vietnamese culture was not understood very well by most people.
And until you understand that culture, it can be very frustrating when all your efforts seem to go for nothing.
It's an entirely different culture than that.
So what lessons should we have learned from being here?
Well, I think there are a great number.
It depends on where you want to start and what area.
Any military lessons?
Well, yeah, I think there are a lot of military lessons learned.
First off, one of the biggest things we learned is that we can project force into a rather hostile environment, into places which are not well-developed.
And the first time I went to Vietnam, I came over the beach, so that would give you an idea.
The next time I landed, no.
So I think that we've learned that we can indeed carry out warfare at all scales in any kind of environment, and we have the ability to do that.
I think we learned some lessons about tour links, command links,
I think we learned some lessons about structure and organization for that type of war, too.
How?
Well, I think that most of the people who were in high-level positions in command had not had that experience, OK?
And having said that, they had had experience in more conventional warfare in, say, Korea in our World War II.
Those conventional formations frequently were not well suited to the job at hand.
And tailoring the forces to the situation and to the mission was very crucial.
Because we initially had forces that were tailored to attack, seize, and hold terrain.
Well, having done that, so what?
You haven't accomplished much because the Vietnamese were perfectly prepared to sit there and see if you're going to sit there 10 years on it.
Were the VC good fighters?
Some were.
Some were excellent fighters.
Some of them were veterans of the wars against the French.
I imagine some of them had been fighting 20 years.
Well, the majority of the VC there were inexperienced.
The NVA were good fighters.
They were professionals.
One of the bigger political lessons learned, I think, was we got confused, in my view, at the political level early.
Because even as early as 65, 66, 67, I used to hear people talking about was there this business of if we drive north, will it draw the Chinese into the war?
Well, I always consider that to be an absolutely ludicrous statement because the Chinese would never have supported the Vietnamese other than in a cursory fashion.
The Russians were supporting the Vietnamese, not the Chinese.
And a lot of people felt that the Vietnamese were
the puppets of the Chinese.
No way.
The Vietnamese and Chinese hate each other.
Certainly there were a great number of Chinese weapons being used by the Vietnamese, but I think that that was misinterpreted as China supplying these.
What it really was is the Russians buying them
and sent them in through China.
Just a convenient way of doing business.
Was there much subversion from the south side?
In South Vietnam, was there much subversion going on?
Sure.
You mean with respect to the local governments and so forth?
Yes, sir.
Oh, absolutely.
Of course, that was a D.C. mission.
Assassination and so forth.
Sure.
That, plus just general indoctrination.
So one of the things that, well, I could spend about an hour talking about what you've got to do with these people.
I think that's kind of important to understand.
Can you briefly describe how they would be different for us, or how ?
I just wrote myself some notes here this afternoon while we were thinking about it.
When you talk about VC, you really have to think of them in terms of people.
The Vietnamese are different.
First off, they've got a group orientation, rather than an individual orientation.
And that's totally alien to the Western society.
Your orientation is individual.
Theirs is as a group.
And they have very strong feelings of community, of Vietnam as a whole, as I say.
They trace their culture back to about 500 B.C.
And they are no stranger to war.
They've been at it since about 500 B.C.
And they've been occupied by several cultures.
The Chinese twice, the Japanese once, the French, the British in recent years.
So they have a...
a kind of, I won't call it nationalistic, more a philosophical idea about the commonality of themselves as a people or as a group rather than as any individual.
And they have a strong sense of their right to statehood as a free and independent state reunited north and south and all of that.
And you really have to take a hard look at the division and how that took place when
were there to understand that as a rather large mistake.
But it had to be done as an expedient to keep the North from just overrunning the South at that time.
Vietnamese have what I call terminal loyalty to this thought of their independence as a people separate from any other people in the world.
And they really have what I would call low esteem for individualism, except for their heroes.
And their heroes are the ones who did things which, you know, they died for the group.
Such as?
Yeah, a lot of them.
So these are the people.
They are very strongly nationalistic.
I noted here that, first off, they've got a sense of shared values.
The Vietnamese people feel that their values are shared all with each other, north or south, and with no one else in the world.
Some of their values are different.
Secondly, they've got a common and unique language.
It's a romanticized, oriental language.
They speak French fluently throughout, and English.
As I say, they're a unique ethnic group because they can find their beginnings way back when.
And they've got about 15% minorities, which are definitely oppressed.
Who would be a minority?
Mainly the tribesmen.
The tribesmen?
Yeah.
I forget on the, was it Montagnards?
Montagnards, yeah.
There are some Cambodian strains, there are some Laotian strains, which are more closely related in commonality to Laotians.
Cambodians don't care for it.
A lot of Chinese live in the big cities.
And they're oppressed?
The Chinese weren't because they were rich.
They went to all the restaurants in Saigon, for example, and things like that.
They are no longer in charge, I'll guarantee you.
They're gone.
They are out of Vietnam.
But the Nords were oppressed?
Yeah.
Assessments in working against fighting the VC and the North Vietnamese were of course enlisted, because they didn't particularly care about, you know, whether they fought them or not.
And for that reason they were more of a mercenary group than one united like the Vietnamese.
One curious thing is the religious mix in Vietnam.

You've got Taoism, you've got Buddhism, you've got Confucianism, you've got Christianity, which is predominantly Catholic, and then you've got a couple of weird offshoots called Khao Dai and Wawa, which are really cults more than religions.
But because of that, there is no strong thread of religion and nationalism.
I don't understand.
Well, what I'm saying is there's no religion which tends to be the national religion.
Okay.
What I'm telling you is religion is subordinated in the Vietnam society to nationalism.
Well, how did such a split occur?
If it's such a nationalistic country, how did... Well, it was political, predominantly.
You have a situation where North Vietnam, predominantly our Ho Chi Minh, was about to swallow the whole country under its Marxist-Leninist philosophy.
I see.
In the South, they felt that they wanted to go it alone independently.
and sought to help the Western nations to do something.
But the infrastructure for the Viet Cong began then.
The VC wasn't something that was invented in the 60s.
They've been there since the 40s.
So I'm afraid a lot of people just don't comprehend what it takes to overcome that.
And you can't sell them Western ideals.

So in my view, the essence of the whole thing is that if you wanted to have a Vietnam that was Western-oriented, and to me there were some good reasons for that, then we had to make the political, societal, and financial commitment to see that was done, which would be a long, long call.
What would it take to do that?
I don't know.
Do you get it?
I don't know.
We didn't have the staying power.
Or, if you will, the national will to stay.
The Vietnamese, particularly when the North came down in the 40s, they essentially decimated all the school teachers.
They executed them.
So the academic structure
was young, and they consider their intellectuals to be part of the elite.
But even the elite have this attitude of loyalty to the nation state over and above an individual or a philosophy.
So that's still .
But you see, the VCs were everywhere.
And they could live in a village undetected
Because when you came to look for them, the people had to think and look at you and wonder, okay, you're here today, where will you be tomorrow?
And if we turn that VC over and you leave, who comes in to find out why we did that?
So there was a strong threat of
retaliation at the village level.
And would that have contributed to the paranoia about, you know, getting bodies and just killing people, like with the VC and infiltrating like that?
I'm not so sure about that.
I think that that was largely, again, an effort to say, hey, we're, you know, we must be winning because we have the bodies that are piled up.
And that's not a good measure.
You're winning when you see...
You know, many other things.
And the VC had a very strong indoctrination problem.
See, they'd come into a village, and they'd round everybody up at night, and they'd bring them in and preach their nationalistic Marxist-Leninist stuff at them for hours and hours on end.
And who was to stop it?
One of the major problems you had in Vietnam, as you do in Central America, is absentee land ownership.
So you've got landowners who live back in the big cities who extract heavy taxes from the farmers and they never see them.
And you've got the DC coming down here saying the land will be yours, our great victory.
They tell them it will be theirs as part of the group.
But still, having ownership as part of a group would be preferable to some of those farmers than the situation they had where they were occupying land that they could never own.
And the best they could do to hope for is make another crop.
So with the VC of the county, how quickly would the North have overrun the South if they had just not had the elections in 58 and then we hadn't intervened?
Would it have been a matter of years?
I don't know.
I wasn't there.
So you can read any book you want to.
Most people think it would have been a matter of months, I think.
Fall and the two Vietnams pretty well documented the strength and structure now.
